did.unittitle: William Wagner personal and business papers and materials relating to the Wagner Free Institute of Science

bioghist.p: William Wagner (1796-1885) was a philanthropist and naturalist. At the age of 16, he was apprenticed to the financier Stephen Girard. In 1816 he was sent as an assistant supercargo on a two-year trading voyage, during which he collected many shell, plant, and fossil specimens. After leaving Girard's employ, he went into business as a shipping merchant with Charles A. Snowden. This partnership was dissolved in 1825, and Wagner continued as a merchant in his own firm. He retired from business in 1840. In 1847, he began to deliver lectures on scientific topics in his home, and, finding that interest in these lectures was strong, founded the Wagner Free Institute of Science in 1855.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of William Wagner's personal correspondence, his remarks on lectures (dated from 1862 to 1887), shipping receipts, and correspondence concerning publication and fossil exchanges. Also included are correspondence and receipts related to the construction of the iron fence around the Institute.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

The Robert Chamber collection (90-015) also contains some personal records of the Wagner family.
